ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

REPRESENTATIONS FROM GOVERNMENT EMPLOYEES
(Secret ballot on union representation)


    1. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Finance (a) whether he has received any representations from the Singapore Federation of Unions of Government Employees requesting a secret ballot among all Government employees other than teachers, senior

Column: 662

officers and daily-rated personnel, with a view to ascertaining whether the majority wish to be represented by unions affiliated to the Federation or to the Amalgamated Union of Public Employees; and (b) what action he proposes to take in the matter.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, a secret ballot of employees is usually taken where an employer refuses to accept an invitation to negotiate on grounds that he does not recognise the union. Where there are two or more unions claiming representation for the same group of employees and the matter cannot be resolved in any other way, a secret ballot can then be taken with the consent of the unions concerned. The Singapore Government has carried on and is carrying on negotiations with the unions affiliated to the Singapore Federation of Unions of Government Employees. No question of recognition therefore arises. A secret ballot on which union is to represent which grade of employees does not, therefore, arise.

    Mr David Marshall: Sir, would the Minister agree that rivalry between these two unions for membership of Government employees is unhealthy? For the unification of the trade union movement in the civil service, does he not consider it appropriate to accede to the request of the Federation?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, there is rivalry not only between unions affiliated to the Federation, hut also between member unions of the Federation themselves. For instance, a stenographer employed in the Broadcasting Division of the Ministry of Culture is eligible for membership and can be represented by one of three unions - the Singapore Government Administrative and Clerical Services Union, the Singapore Secretarial Staff Union, and the Department of Broadcasting Employees' Union. I think in these matters, Sir, it is best to leave questions of representation and negotiations to the employees and their unions.

    Mr David Marshall: If it please you, Mr Speaker, could I have a reply to my question? It is this: Does the Minister

Column: 663

not consider that it would be helpful to the unification of the trade union movement in the civil service if he were to accede to the request of the Federation for a secret ballot to see whether A.U.P.E. or the Federation should have the membership?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: I do not think a secret ballot will solve anything. One of the requests of the Federation is that if they should win the secret ballot, then they ask the Government to require the A.U.P.E. to amend its rules so that they would not be able to recruit Government employees. This same request was made by the Federation of City Council Labour Unions during the last strike, and we pointed out quite clearly to them that it is not within the power of the Government to require any union to amend its laws in the way that the Government thinks fit. Therefore, whether or not a secret ballot is carried out, whether or not the Government recognises one union or the other, the unions concerned will continue to exist, will continue to recruit members, and will continue to compete with each other.

    The Prime Minister: The problem only rises when we refuse recognition.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: The problem arises only, when as I have mentioned before, we refuse recognition to a particular union.

WATER SITUATION
(Statement by the Prime Minister)


    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Sir, I want to report to the House on the water situation.

    Heavy rainfall over the whole Island in the past 10 days, including 4.32 inches for Tuesday, the 16th of January, alone, has brought water stock in our Singapore Reservoirs to full capacity, Rainfall for the month of January up to yesterday, 24th January, has been 14.95 inches as against the January average of 9 inches for the last 86 years. This has enabled the Water Department temporarily to lift rationing and to supply our total consumer needs solely from our Singapore Reservoirs. This will also take advantage of the Singapore rains while conserving stocks in our Johore Reservoirs which are still low because there were no correspondingly heavy rains there in the last fortnight.

    However, the general situation of our total stocks is not altogether satisfactory. About two-thirds of our water stocks are in our Johore Reservoirs of Pontian and Gunong Pulai and these are only 53 per cent of the full capacity, making a 47 per cent shortage. However, in expectation of further rainfall for the rest of January and normal rainfall for February rationing is being lifted.

    The Water Department does not expect water rationing to become necessary again unless a drought were to recur later in the year. Everyone can help by checking waste either in homes or at public standpipes.

    Sir, the summary of the figures for the Johore reservoirs, which I propose to table, reads as follows:

    Gunong Pulai, total capacity, 1,220 million gallons: shortage, 550 million gallons.

    Pontian, maximum capacity, 2,525 million gallons: shortage, 1,218 million gallons.

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I understood the Prime Minister to say that he is now drawing from Singapore

Column: 665

stocks, for the total supply for Singapore would be assure the House that the stocks that go into the consumer taps are properly and adequately treated?

    The Prime Minister: Sir, I think it is the duty of both the Water Department and the City Analyst to ensure that Members of this Assembly and the public generally can continue to enjoy the privilege of living in Singapore which is one of the few cities in South-East Asia where you can consume water off the tap.

    Mr David Marshall: Hear, hear!

FEDERATION OF MALAYSIA


2.40 p.m.

    Order read for resuming adjourned debate.

    Mr Speaker: The Original Question, as amended, was:

    "That, in pursuance of the national objective of a united Malayan nation, enlarged and strengthened by the addition of our brothers in the Borneo territories, this House declares its support in principle for the plan proposed by the Prime Minister of the Federation of Malaya, Tunku Abdul Rahman Putra Al-Haj, and agreed to in principle in the Federation Parliament on 18th October, 1961, for the establishment of the Federation of Malaysia, comprising the eleven States of the present Federation, the States of Singapore and Brunei, and the territories of Sarawak and North Borneo.".

Since which amendments have been proposed,

    In line 4, to leave out "plan" and insert "motion":

    In line 6, to leave out "in principle".

    The Question is, "That the word `plan' proposed to be left out, be left out." As has been indicated, the debate may proceed not only on the Original Question, as amended, but also on those two amendments which have been proposed.

2.42 p.m.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Chan Chee Seng)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I spoke on this motion in this House yesterday. Before concluding, I

Column: 666

said that the Barisan Sosialis had one failing, i.e., they are unable to distinguish clearly who are the colonialists and who are the nationalists. The Barisan Sosialis think that the nationalists are also colonialists. They are confused between the two. That is why their position is isolated today.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the Barisan Sosialis have another failing, i.e., they are shortsighted. They try all ways and means to attack the nationalists - even harder than the attack they level at the colonialists. This is a very great shortcoming of theirs. They hope that the nationalists will come to a united front with them. But they stab the nationalists behind their backs. For example, the Member for Queenstown said yesterday that the Federation of Malaya is attracted to the Malaysia plan because perhaps of the oil resources in Brunei, where the revenue is high. In fact, the revenue there exceeds expenditure so much that there is a great surplus of money which will be helpful to the Federation of Malaya. According to him, this is perhaps the only true appeal that the Malaysia concept has for the Federation of Malaya. This talk is very bad because he is trying to treat the Tunku as an exploiter. He tried to say that when two countries wish to merge, it is a case of exploitation of one by the other. This kind of talk will only further separate the people of the two territories. It will not bring peace to the people: instead it will bring disaster. We in the P.A.P. have a different concept of Malaysia than that of the Barisan Sosialis. We take into consideration the interest of the broad masses of the people. But the attitude' of the Barisan Sosialis towards Malaysia is in the interest of the colonialists.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, today the Barisan Sosialis are in such a position that they are surrounded by enemies. They hope to be able to defeat the P.A.P. in order to gain power so that they can collaborate with the British colonialists.

    The Member for Queenstown raised three points yesterday in his speech with regard to the British colonialists.

Column: 667

This was reported in the Sin Chew Jit Poh. He said the question confronting us is not merely to get rid of the British. I think the people will understand their hidden intention behind this statement. He continued to say - as is reported in the Sin Chew Jit Poh - that the British hoped that the people of the Borneo territories would be divided and fight among themselves, with the result that the colonial influence would be forgotten for the time being by them. At the beginning the Barisan Sosialis said that the question of the British colonialists no longer exists. The second point they raised was that it is the hope of the British to divide the people of the Borneo territories. This kind of talk is very inconsistent. The P.A.P. want to merge all these territories into a very strong Malaysian nation, but the Barisan Sosialis say that it is the intention of the British to divide the people in these territories. If this is so, how can they say that the P.A.P. are trying to sell out the interest of the people in this region? As far as we can see, the leaders of the Barisan Sosialis are suffering from shortsightedness. They seem to be standing on Clifford Pier from where they can see monkeys coming across the sea from Indonesia. They then run quickly to Geylang Serai to say that the enemies are landing and that the Dutch military forces are slaughtering the Indonesian people. They are trying to describe the present situation in Indonesia as a very serious situation in order to agitate innocent womenfolk to go to the battlefield in Indonesia. The leaders of the Barisan Sosialis are just keeping quiet. Instead of doing something, they are shouting slogans on the stage. Such an attitude is incompatible with the interest of the people.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I can see today that the Barisan Sosialis are suffering from a very great mistake. They have many theories and many slogans, but these are at variance with the dialectical materialism of Karl Marx. We know that in the view of Marx, resort must be made to practical moves. The understanding of the human being is very important. The experiences of a

Column: 668

human being must depend on his production in material wealth in order that he can understand the natural resources. The leaders of the Barisan Sosialis only know how to shout slogans on the stage. They know how to talk about theories.

    Mr David Marshall (Anson): On a point of order. Mr Speaker, I understood that we were discussing Malaysia and not the failings of the Barisan Sosialis.

    Mr Speaker: If the Parliamentary Secretary is replying to certain arguments put forward by the Member for Queenstown, which in themselves went a bit far away from the motion, then I think he is entitled to answer those points, but not in too great detail, of course.

    Mr Chan Chee Seng(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am now concentrating on the points raised by the Member for Queenstown which I think are unreasonable.

    Just now I was saying that the Members of the Barisan Sosialis have a lot of theories without being able to understand the actual requirements of the people. They went to Geylang Serai in order to get the support of the Malays there. They appear to be friends of the Malays. They wish to appear to the Malays that they are very courageous in their struggle against colonialism. They try to create a false impression in the minds of the Malays. On the one hand, they try to get the support of the Prime Minister of the Federation, but, on the other hand, they attack him in many ways. They treat the Malays in the Federation in the same way that the Manchurians tried to conquer China. This will widen the gulf between the people of Singapore and the Federation with no benefit to them. For example, in the speeches of the Member for Queenstown, stress is often laid on the fact that Singapore and the other territories should merge with Indonesia. But their real intention is not a reunification of these territories with Indonesia because they understand that the present ruler of Indonesia

Column: 669

is President Soekarno. They think that when Indonesia falls into the hands of the Reds with the fall of President Soekarno, it would then be the proper time to include these territories in the Indonesian Plan.

    In conclusion, I would like to quote what the Member for Queenstown said. This appears on the fifth page of the Sin Chew Jit Poh: of yesterday:

    `As socialists, we are in support of more and more people in various countries uniting together. We want to have more countries united together in the interest of the people building a socialist country with a socialist economic development.'

We in the P.A.P. are trying to bring about a reunification of these territories in the form of Malaysia in order to create a greater nation with a stronger economic unit.

2.55 p.m.

    Dato Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat (Geylang Serai): Mr Speaker, Sir, what is before us today is not the problem of whether this or that Party is going to survive and run the government of Singapore but the future of 10 million people whose destiny is at stake and whose fate is in the balance.

    When the Prime Minister of the Federation of Malaya first mooted the idea, there were rumblings from various quarters particularly from the Communist front organisations, that the conception of Malaysia was the brainchild of British colonialism and British vested interests. These Communist front organisations went even so far as to say that the Tunku had connived with the British in presenting Malaysia.

    Since then, Sir, events have proved to the contrary. The Malaysia Solidarity Consultative Committee in their deliberations in Jesselton, Kuching and Kuala Lumpur, have in no uncertain terms bared the falsehoods and lies of the Communists.

    British colonialism is on its last legs in this part of the world. It is on the way out. The British know it, the Communists know it, and we know it. At the same time, we all know that with the departure of the British colonial

Column: 670

power, there will be left a vacuum in this region. The Communists and their allies, with their tongue in their cheek, say that it will be filled by another form of colonialism - the colonialism of the Federation of Malaya.

    Sir, it is hardly necessary for me to say that neither the Tunku nor his erstwhile colleagues have any territorial ambitions. However, we who belong to the democratic forces have no doubts in our minds that unless something is done - and done quickly - to fill this vacuum, the Communists will get there first.

    The fight for Malaysia is a fight against time. It is a fight for the survival of democracy against the evil forces of Communist dictatorship. The Communists are no fools. They are aware of it. That is why they are using every means in their power, by infiltration, intimidation and persuasion, to wreck the Malaysia Plan. They are fighting for time too. They are not ready to take over now but they hope to do so as soon as they have marshalled their Communist front organisations and dupes in these territories.

    Sir, I do not say that the Communists are the only forces which are against Malaysia, but I dc say this, that they are the biggest force with which the people of Malaysia will have to contend. Even in the Borneo territories, the leaders there have a fair idea of what will happen to them should the Communists succeed. In fact, the few who are apprehensive about Malaysia are those who fear that with the coming of Malaysia the Communist front in Singapore will infiltrate into their territories and make life a misery for them.

    This is one of the fears expressed and it is a very genuine one. For this very reason, Sir, the Temanggong Juga of Iban and other leaders from Sabah and Sarawak insisted that they would very much like to control migration in the respective territories after Malaysia, The people of Sabah, Brunei and Sarawak are fully aware of the dangers of Communism and Communist infiltration.

Column: 671

They know that for them to survive there is no other alternative but to join hands with their kith and kin in Malaya and Singapore in a greater federation and together unfold a new era of prosperity and happiness for all.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like now to touch on some of the points raised by the leader of the Barisan Sosialis in his speech yesterday. Merger and Malaysia mean an enslavement of the people and the spread of injustice and inequality, so said the leader of the Barisan Sosialis. Sir, [do not know how the Member has arrived, at this conclusion. If he had taken the Federation of Malaya today as a guide for the things to come in the future Malaysia, then he is completely wrong. And it is a mischievous and a misleading statement to make. Malaya has been independent for nearly 4½ years. It has proved to the world that amongst the new nations in post World War II it .is a shining example of a country where justice, equality, and freedom of the individual prevail. Malaya has not reached the stage and will not reach the stage of some countries where political opponents are just lugged into prison to satisfy the whims of the ruling Party.

    Talking about enslavement, injustice and inequality, the Member for Thomson, who was my fellow traveller to the Kuching conference, will certainly bear me out when I say that in the Borneo States the ra'ayat, particularly the indigenous people, have not had a square deal from the colonial regime. Injustice, inequality, and enslavement are phases which could be applied to the state of affairs in some of the Borneo territories. Colonial power which came to Sarawak in 1941, in Brunei in 1888, and in Sabah in 1878, had done very little to uplift the standard of living of the indigenous people. When the British first went there, the Dayaks, the Ibans, the Malays, the Muruts, the Bajaus, the Melanaus, the Dusuns, were all living in attap huts. Today, Sir, after decades of colonial administration applied to the people, they are no better. So, when the leader of the Barisan Sosialis talks of injustice,

Column: 672

inequality, and enslavement in the future Malaysia, he should, first of all, take a peep into the conditions that prevail in the Borneo States. I know he has been there, Sir, but perhaps he has not used his eyes wisely.

    Again, Malaysia, says the Barisan leader, would mean the transfer of power from the British to the Federation with the British the back-seat drivers. Sir, I do not see the logic of this argument. We have repeatedly said in this House - and so has the Tunku elsewhere - that Malaysia, like the present Federation of Malaya, will be a free and an independent country. There will be no back-seat drivers. All the drivers in the future Malaysia will come from the people of Malaysia, and they will occupy front seats, except perhaps the Communists who in an open conflict with the nationalist forces would prefer to remain back-seat drivers and let the stooges do the fighting for them.

    Sir, the point has also been raised, within the context of this argument, of the story of nuclear weapons in Singapore and the defence treaty with Britain, and how these arrangements would automatically place the population in the front line in any nuclear war. I myself do not know whether there are nuclear weapons stored in Singapore. But let me tell the Barisan leader and his friends that in the event of a nuclear war erupting in this region, the front line would not be confined to the population of Singapore alone, but the whole world would be involved.

    Sir, mud-slinging and smearing are all effective weapons for those who have no argument left. And so the Barisan Sosialis leaders, having come to the end of their resources, now indulge in this dirty pastime. The Tunku says that their leader, that is, the Member for Queenstown, has a pathological fear of the Chinese in Singapore, and hence he has categorically stated that he would not have Singapore without the Borneo States. The reason, according to the Barisan, is the desire of the Tunku to have a preponderance of the indigenous people over the Chinese. In fact, Sir, this statement is an accusation that the

Column: 673

Tunku is anti-Chinese. Now, nothing can be further from the truth. My friend and colleague, the Member for Cairnhill, has already dealt with this point and I will not elaborate on it. But let me say this, and let me explain, if an explanation is needed, why the Tunku made that statement. It is not because he fears the preponderance of the Chinese. Even with the Borneo territories thrown in, the proportion of racial representation in Malaysia would be 42 per cent indigenous, which would include the Malays, 38 per cent Chinese, 10 per cent Indians and Pakistanis, and 10 per cent others. Sir, knowing the speed of propagation of our Chinese brothers and sisters, I think it would not be long before they catch up with the Malays and even beat them. If we are to fight Communism in Malaysia, we cannot fight them in pockets. The problem must be tackled as a whole. Just as Malaysia without the Borneo territories cannot work; so also Malaysia without Singapore cannot be effective.

    So, Sir, let me once again say to the Barisan boys: our Tunku is not anti-Chinese, nor is he communal in his attitude towards the basic problems facing Malaysia. But it is obvious to all that the very fact that the Barisan has chosen to propound this line of argument only goes to prove the strength of Chinese chauvinism that permeates and guides the thoughts and minds of the Barisan leaders.

    The Member for Queenstown, Sir, has also laboured at great length on the apprehensions of the people of Borneo towards Malaysia. He said the Sarawak United People's Party and the Party Ra'ayat of Brunei wanted self-determination first before having anything to do with Malaysia. Perhaps the Barisan boys can tell me who are the guiding lights of the S.U.P.P. and who are their supporters, and from what group do they come. Are the Party Ra'ayat and the S.U.P.P. the only political Parties in the Borneo States? Does the Member for Queenstown know or has he heard of the Brunei United Party, the Brunei National Organisation -

    Mr S. T. Bani (Thomson): Kosong!

    Dato Abdul Hamid: You say kosong. You will know some day, chum!

    Mr Speaker: Order. I suppose the Member does know that he is addressing the Chair. I do not think the Chair minds being called a chum, but I think he should try and remember that he is addressing the Chair.

    Coming back to the Parties concerned, if I might repeat again. There is the Brunei United Party, the Brunei National Organisation, the Brunei United National Organisation, the Sarawak National Organisation, the Pemuda of Sarawak, the Malay Union of Sarawak, the Party Negara of Sarawak, the Kadazan Party of Sabah, and finally the United Sabah National Organisation, also from Sahah. Of course, Sir, the Barisan boys can only -

    Mr Speaker: Order. If the expression "Barisan boys" is meant to apply to Members, possibly the best phrase would be "Barisan Members".

    Dato Abdul Hamid: I meant the boys of the Barisan outside the Assembly as well, Sir, but I seem to be forgetting that there is also a girl behind it. The Barisan Members can only see what their masters want them to see.

    Sir, I have attended many of the meetings of these organisations. I have met some of their leaders who are not only respectable citizens in their own right but also patriots who love freedom and independence. But I can say this explicitly and without contradiction, that they have not only as a group but in some cases individually a bigger following than the Sarawak United People's Party. So let me advise the Barisan Members, when they talk of Malaysia in the context of the Borneo territories - let them not forget that the Sarawak United People's Party is not the only political Party in Sarawak.

    Sir, during the debate on West Irian, the Member for Thomson had occasion to mention the conception of Greater Malaysia which would include Indonesia, the Philippines, the Borneo States, Singapore and Malaya. Yesterday the Member for Queenstown again extolled the same conception. Sir, I do not know what game the Barisan are playing. Are they really serious about this? Are they trying to delude the people into believing that they support this idea? Perhaps. Sir, I should mention here that the Greater Malaysia plan was first mooted in the early 1930s. The idea caught on until it came out in one of the platforms of the Malay National Party, or M.N.P. after World War II.

    Mr David Marshall rose -

    Mr Speaker: Point of order?

    Mr David Marshall: Point of clarification. Sir.

    Mr Speaker: If the Member will give way.

    Dato Abdul Hamid resumed his seat.

    Mr David Marshall: I am much obliged. I am very interested in that statement, Sir. Could the Member indicate who first initiated that concept? And where can I find documentation for it?

    Dato Abdul Hamid: I am coming to that, Sir, but I do not think I would like to mention the name of the gentleman who first mooted the idea. It came from the Philippines. Anyway, politically and economically it was an idea acceptable to the Malay masses. But do the Barisan really know the primary objective of the conception of this so-called Greater Malaysia? I will tell you, Sir,It was an anti-Chinese move. It was a move which emanated from certain national leaders in South-East Asia who feared the insurgence of Chinese in the Malaysian world. Sir, had they known about this so-called Greater Malaysia, I am sure the idea would not be as attractive to them now as it was before. And yet. Mr Speaker, they have the cheek to say that the Tunku is anti-Chinese when he refused to consider the concept of this Greater Malaysia.

    Sir, when winding up his speech, the Barisan leader said that Malaysia is a British-sponsored project. I will not attempt to deny this allegation. But to end up my speech, I will say this to the Barisan Members and to all those who are anti-Malaysia. The question I would like to put to them is this. "Do you want to run your country yourselves or do you want to let the Communists run it for you? If you want to run it yourselves, then the only answer is Malaysia."
